Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Type I: A Taste of Computing: Adding a CS Entree to the Education Choices in a Large Urban School District

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration: DePaul University and Loyola University of Chicago propose a project to improve and expand computer science (CS) education in Chicago Public Schools (CPS) high schools. The project will create a high-quality CS course that will serve as the introductory course for all tracks of the three-year CPS Career and Technology Education InfoTech (CTE InfoTech) program that is offered at 32 high schools. The course will adapt and extend the successful pilot "Exploring Computer Science" (ECS) curriculum originally developed for the Los Angeles Unified School District. With a focus on computational thinking, the ECS curriculum includes units on Human Computer Interaction, Problem Solving, Web Design, Programming, Computing Applications, and Robotics. This project will create new units on Game Programming and Project Management as alternatives to the Robotics unit. These new units won?t require expensive technology, facilitating the adoption of ECS in a wider range of schools; in addition, they will also better serve some of the tracks being introduced in the newly revamped CTE InfoTech curriculum. To increase adoption beyond the CTE program, the new course is likely to be offered also as a Mathematics elective and it will be a great preparatory course for the new AP Computer Science Principles course that is being developed. Finally, the CPS high school population is 51% African American and 37% Hispanic, making Chicago an ideal location to reach students from underrepresented groups, and leveraging the expertise of the PIs, specific efforts will also be made to achieve a more equitable representation of the female half of the population.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Taste of Computing (ToC) project has set on course a major transformation of computer science education in the Chicago Public Schools. It also has greatly influenced other school districts across the nation to pursue a similar trajectory. The project has incorporated all three pillars of the NSF program under which it was funded: computer science content (incorporating meaningful conceptual education rather than computer literacy training), broadening participation (reaching students in demographic groups that are underrepresented in computing), and education research (including evaluation of the impact on teachers and students of professional development and the ensuing new instruction). This program responds to both a national need for more individuals with strong computing skills and also inequities in career opportunities among various demographic groups.


Through this project and an ensuing partnership between Chicago Public Schools and the non-profit code.org to continue our work, dozens of teachers have participated in transformational professional development activities and have begun delivering valuable computer science education to several thousand students annually. The project has involved much more than dissemination of a curriculum, with a strong focus on teaching methodologies as well. The professional development for the course initially introduced by this project has emphasized three interwoven strands: computer science content, equity-based teaching practices, and an inquiry-based learning environment.


Teachers have expressed overwhelming enthusiasm for the professional development provided by this project, and students are extraordinarily inspired. In addition, new types of students are beingserved; we are reaching many women and minority students, groups that have traditionally been underrepresented in computing.


In addition to increasing the pool of computer science teachers and the number and diversity of students studying computing, we have facilitated the blossoming of an extensive community of teachers and administrators dedicated to cultivating and expanding modern computer science education in CPS and beyond. The push for providing high-quality computing education has become well-established within the CPS culture in a way that is enduring beyond the life of the grant.


While the grant initially focused on broad establishment of an introductory computer science course in CPS high schools, there is now tremendous momentum towards establishment of multiple computing courses at the high school level, introduction of computing curricula in K--8 grades, and rapid expansion in the number of participating schools.
